texts.value: Catalyzes the formation of fatty acid-cholesterol esters, which are less soluble in membranes than cholesterol (PubMed:16154994, PubMed:16647063, PubMed:32433613, PubMed:32433614, PubMed:32944968, PubMed:9020103). Plays a role in lipoprotein assembly and dietary cholesterol absorption (PubMed:16154994, PubMed:9020103). Preferentially utilizes oleoyl-CoA ((9Z)-octadecenoyl-CoA) as a substrate: shows a higher activity towards an acyl-CoA substrate with a double bond at the delta-9 position (9Z) than towards saturated acyl-CoA or an unsaturated acyl-CoA with a double bond at the delta-7 (7Z) or delta-11 (11Z) positions (PubMed:11294643, PubMed:32433614)

reaction.name: a sterol + a long-chain fatty acyl-CoA = a long-chain 3-hydroxysterol ester + CoA
cholesterol + an acyl-CoA = a cholesterol ester + CoA

texts.value: Cholesterol O-acyltransferase activity is inhibited by nevanimibe
Homotetramer; composed of two homodimers (PubMed:32433613, PubMed:32433614). Interacts with UBIAD1 (PubMed:23169578)
Highly activated by the presence of cholesterol

Each protomer consists of 9 transmembrane segments, which enclose a cytosolic tunnel and a transmembrane tunnel that converge at the predicted catalytic site: acyl-CoA enters the active site through the cytosolic tunnel, whereas cholesterol enters from the side through the transmembrane tunnel
Belongs to the membrane-bound acyltransferase family. Sterol o-acyltransferase subfamily

features.description: Nearly normal expression and enzyme activity.
Low expression, loss of enzymatic activity.
In QQ mutant; almost abolished cholesterol O-acyltransferase activity.
Abolished homodimerization; when associated with A-367.
